Venusaur.overview: Venusaur is an excellent Grass-type attacker when paired with sun setters like Torkoal. With a Chlorophyll boost, it can outspeed some of the metagame's fastest threats like Regieleki, Pheromosa, and Dragapult. Venusaur has an incredible offensive and supportive presence, as it can either wear down foes over the course of a game with G-Max Vine Lash and immobilize threats with a fast Sleep Powder. It also has access to both Max Quake and Max Ooze to boost its Special Defense and Special Attack in addition to its already great natural bulk. It's this wide array of options that can make Venusaur very hard to predict against. However, Venusaur is far less effective if sun is not active, meaning it can struggle against Pokemon with ways to change the weather like Pokemon with access to Max Rockfall or Max Hailstorm. Additionally, Sleep Powder's poor accuracy means that misses will occur somewhat often, putting Venusaur on the backfoot quickly. Its Grass typing also makes it a prime target for common Max Airstream users such as Zapdos and Galarian Moltres.
Venusaur.comments:
Other Options

Coba Berry can be used as a fringe option to provide insurance against Max Airstream users like Zapdos and Thundurus if Focus Sash has already been taken on its team. Similarly, Weakness Policy can be used to turn the tides on Flying- and Fire-type attackers, but is useless without activation.

sets.name: Chlorophyll
sets.description:
• Leaf Storm is used to give Venusaur both a powerful G-Max Vine Lash and a strong STAB move to use while outside of Dynamax. Having a Grass-type move is essential for hitting the likes of Tapu Fini and Regirock. Frenzy Plant can be used for a stronger G-Max Vine Lash at the cost of a less reliable STAB attack while not Dynamaxed.

  • Earth Power allows Venusaur to hit Incineroar and Steel-types such as Metagross and Stakataka while boosting its Special Defense with Max Quake, while Sludge Bomb can hit Grimmsnarl and boost its Special Attack with Max Ooze.

  • Weather Ball is an excellent option for hitting both Steel-types and opposing Grass-types such as Kartana and Rillaboom. Unfortunately, its reliance on sun means it cannot always be used successfully.

  • Sleep Powder is a way for Venusaur to immobilize major threats such as Dragapult and Regieleki while its partner goes on the offensive.

  • Focus Sash is typically used alongside Sleep Powder to give Venusaur increased security in the event that it misses. Life Orb is more commonly used on three attacks + Protect sets that are looking to increase damage output and use Venusaur in Dynamax as often as possible.

Charizard.overview: When given the freedom to attack under sun, Charizard is one of the metagame's most threatening sweepers. With the high number of Grass- and Steel-type Pokemon currently seeing play, it has no hard time finding ideal targets to melt with its strong STAB moves, such as Metagross, Kartana, and Rillaboom. Charizard's damage output is insanely high, both because of its high Special Attack and Solar Power as well as the residual damage done at the end of each turn by G-Max Wildfire. Additionally, it can even boost its Speed and Special Defense thanks to Max Airstream and Max Quake. Unfortunately, Charizard has a hard time answering faster Electric-types such as Regieleki and Thundurus. Bulky Ground-types such as Garchomp and Landorus-T are also able to live its powerful attacks and retaliate with Max Rockfall.
Charizard.comments:
Other Options

  • Charti Berry is nice for surviving a Max Rockfall from Landorus-T and Garchomp, but is useless otherwise. A Choice Scarf set can be used to catch faster threats off guard, but it can't be abused when Dynamaxed.

sets.name: Solar Power Gigantamax
sets.description:
• Blast Burn makes for the strongest possible G-Max Wildfire, but Heat Wave gives Charizard a more consistent spread attacking option outside of Gigantamax. Whichever Fire-type move is chosen, G-Max Wildfire has no hard time destroying the likes of Metagross and Celesteela.

  • Hurricane and Air Slash provide Charizard with access to Max Airstream, with the former offering more power and the latter more accuracy. Due to the high usage of Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Kartana, Charizard will find opportunities to use Max Airstream and grab a +1 Speed boost often.

  • Scorching Sands is an option for access to Max Quake, allowing Charizard to hit the likes of Incineroar and Regieleki while boosting its Special Defense. Solar Beam lets Charizard effectively hit Water-types such as Tapu Fini and Lapras either in sun or with Max Overgrowth.

  • The combination of Life Orb and Solar Power is used to ensure Charizard's attacks are as strong as possible. Since its goal is to deal heavy and fast damage, it typically does not mind the recoil from Solar Power and Life Orb. Safety Goggles can be used for teams that need dedicated counterplay to Venusaur and Amoonguss.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With its Gigantamax forme, Blastoise is a potent offensive Water-type threat that threatens Pokemon such as Incineroar and Landorus-T.

  • Water Spout is Blastoise's primary STAB move, providing it with a strong spread move and a 150-Base Power G-Max Cannonade. Hydro Cannon is an alternative to Water Spout that provides a more consistent attacking option when not Dynamaxed.

  • Ice Beam lets Blastoise stand up to Pokemon that would otherwise check it, such as Rillaboom, Zapdos, and Thundurus. While Blizzard is inaccurate, if Blastoise sets hail with Max Hailstorm, it can be a good option when not Dynamaxed. It also has the benefit of giving a stronger Max Move.

  • Fake Out allows Blastoise to disrupt opposing Pokemon, possibly giving your Pokemon and ease pressure from its partner, while Shell Smash transforms it from a decent to an excellent attacker.

  • Life Orb is Blastoise's primary item to boost its otherwise average offensive presence. Mystic Water is also used because its lack of recoil. White Herb can be used to reverse the Defense drops from Shell Smash. Blastoise's Speed investment allows it to outspeed Incineroar and Heatran.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• With good overall bulk, decent defensive typing, and a great supportive movepool, Blastoise carves itself a niche as a good utility Pokemon. With Yawn, Fake Out, Haze and Icy Wind, Blastoise is able to disrupt the opposing Pokemon in multiple facets of the game.

  • Scald is Blastoise's attacking move of choice due to its chance to burn, which is particularly relevant against prominent physical attackers such as Glastrier, Garchomp and Urshifu-S.

  • Fake Out allows Blastoise to disrupt a Pokemon of its choice, either pinning it down for a KO or allowing a teammate to set up.

  • Icy Wind's speed control against both opposing Pokemon is good for letting slower Pokemon outspeed faster threats like Regieleki and Spectrier.

  • Haze is particularly potent against setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Garchomp and Nasty Plot Spectrier. It can also be used to reset negative stat changes to Blastoise's teammate, such as Attack drops from Intimidate.

  • Yawn is a good support option to force either undesired switches or crippling status, and it is especially useful for punishing Dynamaxing.

  • Sitrus Berry provides Blastoise with additional longevity, allowing it to perform its supportive role for longer. Wacan Berry allows Blastoise to take an attack from even the most threatening Electric-types, such as Regieleki. It is also useful for using Haze to clear an opposing Rotom's Nasty Plot boost.

  • Blastoise's defensive investment allows it to survive Grassy Glide from Miracle Seed Rillaboom, and Volt Switch from Magnet Regieleki.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Raichu is a great supporting option for Electric-weak Dynamax attackers, using Lightning Rod to absorb Electric-type moves. Raichu also has access to a wide supporting movepool including, but not limited to, Fake Out, Nuzzle, and Eerie Impulse.

  • Nuzzle is great to paralyze fast threats, allowing allies to outspeed them. Full paralyses can also stall out the opponent's Dynamax.

  • Eerie Impulse and Charm are two moves that respectively lower foes' Special Attack and Attack by two stages. Eerie Impulse can cripple threats such as Venusaur, Celesteela, and Galarian Moltres, whereas Charm can cripple Landorus-T, Urshifu-S, and Cinderace.

  • Volt Switch is a great momentum gaining move that can also trigger the Weakness Policy of allies such as Galarian Moltres and Gigantamax Lapras.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Clefairy can provide amazing support to its teammates, whether it's from Follow Me, Friend Guard, or any of its other plethora of support options.

  • Follow Me is an excellent move to support frailer teammates such as Spectrier and Urshifu-S, letting them attack free of charge. Follow Me can also absorb Max Moves, as all of them are single-targeting moves.

  • Sing, while inconsistent, can be extremely deadly. Pokemon such as Metagross may Dynamax and target Clefairy's threatening partner, such as Dragapult or Spectrier, only to get put to sleep by Sing and effectively waste its Dynamax. However, Helping Hand is a more consistent alternative useful for increasing the damage output of Clefairy's teammate.

  • Dazzling Gleam provides Clefairy with a spread move to pick off weakened foes as well as break Focus Sashes. Moonblast is a stronger alternative to Dazzling Gleam that can also drop the foe's Special Attack, but it doesn't have the benefit of being a spread move. Clefairy can also ditch any attacking moves and go with After You, which is useful for letting fast teammates such as Kartana and Thundurus still move first under Trick Room.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With a brilliant unique item in Thick Club, a respectable Speed stat for Trick Room, and access to Lightning Rod, Alolan Marowak is a great offensive Pokemon for Trick Room and balance teams.

  • Flare Blitz is Alolan Marowak's strongest Fire-type STAB move, responsible for handling common Fire-weak Pokemon such as Rillaboom, Celesteela, and Venusaur. Max Flare can also set sun for Alolan Marowak, boosting the power of its Fire-type move and mitigating its Water weakness.

  • Shadow Bone is Alolan Marowak's most consistent Ghost-type STAB move that also comes with a chance to lower the foe's Defense, making its next hit even stronger; Poltergeist is a stronger alternative, but its lower accuracy and reliance on the opponent still having an item make it less consistent. These both provide access to Max Phantasm, lowering the opposing Pokemon's Defense for physically attacking partners such as Urshifu-R and Kartana and making Alolan Marowak increasingly more threatening as the drops stack.

  • Bonemerang allows Alolan Marowak to notably beat Incineroar, as well as hitting Heatran and Coalossal 4x super effectively. It also gives Alolan Marowak Max Quake when Dynamaxed, patching up its otherwise meager Special Defense.

  • Lightning Rod is the best ability for Alolan Marowak, as it allows it to support Electric-weak partners such as Celesteela and Tapu Fini nicely. It also redirects Eerie Impulse from Thundurus and Porygon2, letting special attacking partners such as Celesteela and Nihilego continue undeterred.

sets.name: Neutralizing Gas Support
sets.description:
• Weezing should only be used with Regigigas due to Neutralizing Gas negating Slow Start.

  • Clear Smog prevents setup sweepers such as Spectrier and Landorus-T from snowballing, as well as resetting Max Move boosts. Sludge Bomb deals more consistent damage but doesn't have the benefit of resetting the stats of the target.

  • Taunt prevents attempts to cripple Weezing's most common partner, Regigigas, with status such as burn from Will-O-Wisp and sleep with Yawn. It also prevents Regigigas from being slowed down by Trick Room attempts from Porygon2 and Dusclops.

  • Will-O-Wisp is great for crippling physical attackers such as Metagross, Glastrier and Urshifu-S.

  • 252 Speed EVs and Timid nature allow Weezing to outspeed notable Pokemon such as Metagross, Porygon2 and Gothitelle. The former is severely crippled by Will-O-Wisp and the latter two are stopped in their tracks by Taunt.

Lapras.overview: Lapras has anchored itself as a premier Dynamax candidate for many defensive teams in the metagame due to its Gigantamax form setting Aurora Veil through G-Max Resonance. Additionally, its offensive sets are strong enough to deal significant damage to several meta staples, like Garchomp, Incineroar, and Landorus-T. Bulkier Perish Song sets offer an alternative win condition if Lapras and its teammates are able to weather the three turns necessary. Lapras is reliant on Dynamax and often finds itself being insignificant on the field after it ends. Due to Lapras's relatively low base Special Attack, it sometimes struggles to pick up KOs, especially due to damage reduction through moves like Snarl and Light Screen. Lapras also dislikes taking hits before Aurora Veil goes up, as its bulk is significantly worse without it.

sets.name: Offensive Gigantamax
sets.description:
• Hydro Pump is the preferred Water-type STAB move as it helps make up for Lapras's low Special Attack, and its higher 140 Base Power Max Geyser is excellent for hitting Entei and Incineroar.

  • Blizzard is preferred on this set so that Lapras gets access to the strongest possible G-Max Resonance, notably making a difference against the likes of Dragapult and Rillaboom.

  • Thunder is used to give Lapras Max Lightning, hitting opposing Water-types like Tapu Fini and denying sleep from moves like Yawn and Spore that would otherwise disrupt it.

  • Life Orb offers an immediate power boost at the cost of Lapras's bulk, whereas Weakness Policy can be used for a larger boost without the drawbacks of recoil, but its damage output will suffer without any boosts.

  • Water Absorb lets Lapras function as a catch-all Water-type switch-in, whereas Shell Armor removes the chance of Lapras being struck by a Critical Hit. Notably this significantly reduces the damage from Urshifu-S's Wicked Blow.

sets.name: Defensive Light Clay
sets.description:
• Hydro Pump is preferred as Lapras wants the power from a 140 Base Power Max Geyser to hit Water-weak Pokemon like Incineroar.

  • Freeze-Dry gives Lapras the consistent damage needed both in and out of Dynamax. Because this set is not focused on damage the secondary effect Freeze Dry offers is preferred. Additionally, it somewhat makes up for the lack of Thunder by hitting Water-types.

  • Perish Song is an incredible endgame win condition due to the immense bulk of defensive Lapras teams under Aurora Veil.

Zapdos.overview: Zapdos's powerful Max Airstream and good Speed stat allow it to be a potent offensive threat in the metagame. In addition, its typing lets it effectively check common Pokemon such as Tapu Fini, Rillaboom, and Kartana. However, as it has no way of increasing its damage output by itself, Zapdos tends to struggle against Snarl users such as Incineroar and screens from Grimmsnarl and Gigantamax Lapras. It also has a hard time dealing with Ground-types like Assault Vest Landorus-T and Garchomp.
Zapdos.comments:
Other Options

Roost can replace Heat Wave and can be ran alongside Detect for increased longevity at the cost of coverage. Thunder is an option when running Zapdos with Politoed for a stronger Max Lightning at the cost of having two weather-reliant STAB moves. Similarly, Weather Ball can be rain over Heat Wave on rain teams for access to Max Geyser.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Hurricane is a powerful secondary STAB move that lets Zapdos boost its Speed with Max Airstream when Dynamaxed as well as hit Grass-types like Rillaboom and Amoonguss.

  • Heat Wave deals spread damage and hits Steel-types like Metagross and Kartana for super effective damage. It also lets Zapdos hit opposing Electric-types like Regieleki and Raichu.

  • Detect allows Zapdos to protect itself when needed and is used over Protect to bypass Imprison users such as Indeedee-M, but Protect's higher PP is helpful against Urshifu-S locked into Sucker Punch. Alternatively, Roost can be used to recover health and stall the foe's Dynamax turns.

  • Life Orb is the most commonly used item, but Safety Goggles is also a good choice because it is helpful against sleep inducers like Amoonguss and Venusaur.

  • Static is chosen over Pressure, as it rarely ever affects the outcome of a game, while Static can trigger against Pokemon like Urshifu-S and Kartana.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Galarian Zapdos's strength lies in launching strong, Defiant-boosted attacks, preferably when Dynamaxed. It can rapidly become unstoppable with boosts from its STAB options in Dynamax, and these options combine to hit most Pokemon in the metagame at least neutrally.

  • Brave Bird is a powerful STAB move that hits threats such as Rillaboom, Venusaur, and Amoonguss. Also, with Max Airstream, it can stack Speed boosts and gain momentum for the team.

  • Close Combat lets Galarian Zapdos OHKO metagame staples like Incineroar, Glastrier, and Porygon2 with a Defiant boost. Alternatively, Thunderous Kick is an option to consider without drawbacks, but it is noticeably weaker initially than Close Combat. Both moves boost Attack as Max Knuckle in Dynamax, further helping Galarian Zapdos snowball.

  • Stomping Tantrum gives Galarian Zapdos coverage to hit Regieleki and Torkoal. Taunt is useful to shut down the opponent's Trick Room or redirection attempts and gain momentum for the team.

  • Throat Chop OHKOes Ghost-types like Spectrier and Dragapult when Galarian Zapdos Dynamaxes. Blaze Kick is an option to hit Celesteela and Metagross, but Stomping Tantrum is usually preferred for access to Max Quake.

  • Assault Vest lets Galarian Zapdos take hits from special attackers such as Rotom-H more frequently outside of Dynamax. Life Orb gives it the immediate power needed to guarantee OHKOs on threats such as Incineroar and Glastrier without relying on Defiant boosts.

Moltres-Galar.overview: Galarian Moltres's access to Nasty Plot, a boosting ability in Berserk, and a powerful Max Airstream make it a threat in the metagame. Max Airstream and Max Darkness are a powerful combination that boosts your Speed and lowers your foe's Special Defense, meaning that Galarian Moltres becomes more dangerous every turn. It also performs incredibly well against Spectrier, Rillaboom, and Kartana, resisting most of their moves and dealing serious damage with its own. However, it is often too reliant on Nasty Plot and Berserk boosts to deal serious damage, meaning it struggles against Eerie Impulse Porygon2 and Snarl users like Incineroar. Galarian Moltres's typing also exposes it to common threats such as Regieleki, Thundurus, and Glastrier.
Moltres-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Taunt can be used over Protect to stop Porygon2 from using Trick Room or Eerie Impulse, but Protect is often preferred to preserve Galarian Moltres's longevity. Sitrus Berry is useful for potentially allowing Berserk to activate a second time.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Fiery Wrath hits Psychic-types like Indeedee-F, Metagross, and Spectrier and has a useful 20% flinching chance. Max Darkness is really useful to lower foes' Special Defense and threaten them even more when Dynamaxed.

  • Air Slash hits threats like Venusaur, Urshifu-S, and Rillaboom and allows Galarian Moltres to make up for its below average Speed, providing Speed boosts to it and its partner with Max Airstream while Dynamaxed. Hurricane can be used over Air Slash to get more power while sacrificing accuracy.

  • Nasty Plot combined with Berserk allows Galarian Moltres to quickly boost its Special Attack and become a threatening offensive presence, capable of quickly sweeping its foes.

  • Life Orb instantly boosts Galarian Moltres's damage output and reduces its reliance on Nasty Plot, whereas Weakness Policy can be used to provide even more stat boosting on bulkier spreads. Safety Goggles lets Galarian Moltres ignore Venusaur's and Amoonguss's powder moves.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:
• Politoed is the strongest rain setter in the metagame thanks to its amazing supporting movepool and survivability. Politoed is usually seen alongside Kingdra, forming a solid rain core able to threaten even the strongest staples of the metagame such as Dragapult, Glastrier, and Coalossal.

  • Scald is capable of hitting metagame staples like Incineroar, Torkoal, and Landorus-T for good damage thanks to its power boost in rain. Scald can also cripple opposing physical attackers like Urshifu-S, Rillaboom, and Glastier with burns. Muddy Water is an option to ignore opposing redirection and spread accuracy drops, but its lower accuracy can be troublesome.

  • Helping Hand gives a boost to Politoed's teammates when attacking. In particular, it helps Kingdra deal with sun teams, allowing it to OHKO Torkoal and Assault Vest Landorus-T in sun with Max Geyser.

  • Perish Song can serve as a strong win condition late-game, as it can force wins on weakened teams that have only two members remaining. Perish Song can also be paired with Gothitelle, as its ability to trap foes can be extremely helpful against passive leads such as Porygon2 + Grimmsnarl. Alternatively, Icy Wind can be used to slow down faster threats such as Spectrier, Zapdos, and Garchomp.

  • Sitrus Berry extends Politoed's survivability. Wacan Berry can be used instead to help Politoed endure Regieleki's Thunderbolt or Thundurus's Max Lighting, but Sitrus Berry is usually preferred, as it can be useful in many more situations. The given EV spread lets Politoed survive Assault Vest Rillaboom's Grassy Glide and Spectrier's Max Phantasm.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• Foul Play enables Umbreon to punish physical attackers like Metagross, Glastrier and Dragapult.

  • Snarl is used in order to reduce the damage output of special attackers such as Spectrier and Tapu Fini.

  • Moonlight allows Umbreon to stay in a match longer and, when combined with its supportive moves, can make it a solid wincon. Sun also boosts Moonlight's recovery.

  • Yawn allows Umbreon to put the opponent's team in an unfavorable position by forcing both foes to switch out or be put to sleep. Taunt allows it to prevent Trick Room attempts from Poyrgon2 or Dusclops and sleep attempts from Amoongus or Venusaur. Helping Hand's support is especially appreciated because Umbreon is frequently paired with heavy-hitters, such as Charizard and Venusaur.

  • Leftovers gives Umbreon increased longevity and Safety Goggles allows it to stand up to common sleep users in Venusaur and Amoongus.

sets.name: Swift Swim Attacker
sets.description:
• Thanks to its ability in Swift Swim, near unresisted STAB combination, and access to Hurricane for Max Airstream, Kingdra is a threatening candidate for Dynamax in the rain. Kingdra matches up well against some of the most common and powerful Pokemon in the format such as Incineroar and Landorus-T. However Kingdra does have a few flaws, such as its reliance on rain due to its average Special Attack and Speed. Additionally, bulkier Grass-types can trouble Kingdra, as they have the bulk to take any of its attacks and pressure it back.

  • Muddy Water is often the preferred Water-type STAB option on Kingdra, as it is a powerful spread move in rain with a chance to lower accuracy. Hydro Pump is a stronger single target alternative that also offers a slightly stronger Max Geyser. These also allow Kingdra to set its own rain with Max Geyser in the absence of Politoed.

  • Draco Meteor is Kingdra's strongest Dragon-type STAB option. Max Wyrmwind lowering the opposing Pokemon's Attack stat is useful in circumventing Kingdra's mediocre bulk.

  • Hurricane hits Grass-types that would otherwise trouble Kingdra like Venusaur, Rillaboom, and Amoonguss. It also lets Kingdra boost its Speed with Max Airstream.

  • Life Orb is Kingdra's best item, as it considerably boosts the power of its attacks for a small amount of recoil. Life Orb is essential to pick up KOs on Dynamaxed Dragapult and Venusaur. The given HP EVs are optimized so that Kingdra takes as little damage from Life Orb as possible. Swift Swim is needed for Kingdra to be a viable Pokemon, which makes Politoed a near obligatory teammate. A Timid nature and 172 Speed EVs let Kingdra outspeed Regieleki in rain.

Porygon2.overview: Porygon2 is one of the most reliable choices for a Trick Room setter in the current metagame. Its one weakness to Fighting-type moves is very easy to account for, and its reliance on Eviolite means it almost never competes with teammates for a specific item slot. Its vast movepool makes it extremely customizable from team to team, ranging from an offensive coverage user to a dedicated Spectrier check and Trick Room setter. If given a Special Attack boost from Download, its offensive capabilities are also quite respectable, especially if it chooses to Dynamax. Unfortunately, due to the high damage output in a format with threats such as Regieleki and Urshifu-S, Porygon2 may sometimes be overwhelmed by strong foes before it can set Trick Room. It's also reliant on boosts for its offensive presence, meaning that without them the opponent can simply just ignore Porygon2's slot until its the last Pokemon remaining.
Porygon2.comments:
Other Options

Icy Wind can be used to deal incremental chip damage to foes while also serving as an alternative form of speed control. An offensive Dynamaxed mixed attacking set with Giga Impact is excellent for catching the opponent off guard while making the most of either Download boost.

sets.name: Trick Room Support
sets.description:
• Tri Attack provides a more consistent attack across the board, as well as an increased chance to inflict status. It also serves as the base move for a hard-hitting Max Strike, which is useful for lowering foes' Speed.

  • Ice Beam is effective for hitting the likes of Rillaboom, Landorus-T, and Zapdos for strong super effective damage. Eerie Impulse lets it cripple Special Attackers like Galarian Moltres and Tapu Fini.

  • Recover is very important for keeping Porygon2 healthy over the course of a game and can be used repeatedly to stall out the foe's Dynamax.

  • Trick Room is Porygon2's most consistent form of speed control. Thanks to its high bulk and one weakness, it's very difficult to deny Porygon2 from setting it up.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• Hitmontop serves as a utility-based Pokemon with access to tools such as Intimidate, Helping Hand, and Fake Out as well as momentum tools such as Feint and Quick Guard that allow its partner to achieve its goals undisturbed.

  • Close Combat is the main source of damage for Hitmontop, allowing to effectively duel threats such as Urshifu-S and Glastrier.

  • Wide Guard is capable of completely nullifying damage output from Kyogre, Groudon, and Expanding Force Calyrex-S. Feint provides the team with another supportive option, allowing highly offensive threats to have their damage output undisturbed. Quick Guard allows the team one-time protection against moves such as Fake Out, which can allow Pokemon that would otherwise be prone to Fake Out such as Zacian-C to do something with their turn.

  • Eject Button is the most consistent method of pivoting with Hitmontop, allowing it to reset its Fake Out and Intimidate. Focus Sash and Coba Berry are alternatives that grant it some survivability against strong Flying-type threats such as Zapdos and Yveltal.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Entei is a good supporting Pokemon that cannot flinch or be weakened by opposing Intimidate due to its ability Inner Focus.

  • Sacred Fire is a strong STAB move with 50% burn chance that can heavily cripple physical attackers, such as Metagross and Dragapult, by halving their Attack.

  • Extreme Speed is a strong priority move that can finish off weakened foes such as Focus Sash Regieleki and Whimsicott.

  • Snarl is useful to soften damage taken by opposing special threats such as Venusaur, Tapu Fini, and Galarian Moltres.

  • Bulldoze can provide speed control and trigger the Weakness Policy of Entei's allies, and it is great combined with Metagross and its ability Clear Body that prevents its Speed from dropping.

  • Stone Edge is a useful coverage option that hits Flying-types such as Zapdos and Charizard while also being helpful to hit Incineroar.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Suicune's great bulk and supporting options allow it to be a great help to its team with moves like Tailwind and Helping Hand. Additionally, it is a nuisance to the opposition with its damage-reducing moves such as Snarl and Scald.

  • Scald is Suicune's Water-type move of choice, as it can severely cripple physical threats such as Glastrier and Metagross with its burn chance.

  • Tailwind allows Suicune's teammates to outspeed fast threats such as Dragapult and Venusaur in sun. Tailwind works especially with Suicune because of its ability Inner Focus, preventing it from getting flinched.

  • Snarl allows Suicune to neuter the damage of special attackers such as Spectrier, Charizard, and Tapu Fini.

  • Ice Beam can hit Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Garchomp for massive damage, as well as Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Whimsicott that Suicune would otherwise struggle with. However, Suicune can also run Helping Hand to increase the damage output of its teammates.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Tyranitar makes an excellent Weakness Policy user thanks to its high Attack and weaknesses to common attacking types like Ground and Steel.

  • Rock Side is a reliable spread move with a respectable damage output. It becomes the base move for Tyranitar's powerful Max Rockfall, easily destroying the likes of Thundurus, Zapdos, and Glastrier.

  • Lash Out is great for punishing opposing Intimidate, as it doubles in power if Tyranitar's stats are lowered. Crunch works just as well if Tyranitar is paired with Intimidate deterrents like Thundurus. In general, teams appreciate Dark-type coverage to threaten Spectrier, Dragapult, and Indeedee-F.

  • Superpower is Tyranitar's preferred filler move, notably allowing it to hit Urshifu-S and opposing Tyranitar for super effective damage while also boosting its Attack with Max Knuckle.

  • Maximum HP investment allows it to consistently beat a variety of common threats including Charizard, Zapdos, and Spectrier.

sets.name: Focus Sash Lead
sets.description:
• Fast Tyranitar is an excellent aggressive lead. It is very effective for spreading paralysis and launching powerful hits early-game.

  • Rock Slide lets Tyranitar hit for consistent spread damage and can potentially land crucial flinches.

  • Jolly Tyranitar is a great Assurance user, as it is often paired with faster teammates like Thundurus and Dracovish, allowing Assurance to hit for double damage. Foul Play is also a strong choice against powerful physical attackers like Landorus-T and Defiant-boosted Thundurus.

  • Thunder Wave can ruin unsuspecting enemy lead Pokemon, which is especially great if it can catch a foe as it Dynamaxes. This opens the door for Tyranitar's teammates to gain momentum and clean up late-game.

  • Taunt works well to shut down attempts to cripple Tyranitar and its partners such as status spreading or Trick Room. Superpower is useful for hitting Kartana and opposing Tyranitar.

  • 252 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature give Tyranitar the best possible chances of crippling its desired target, while maximum Attack investment ensures it can still pack a punch. Focus Sash makes up for the lack of bulk investment.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Torkoal is a reliable option to set sun for Charizard and Venusaur to wreak havoc with their abilities.

  • Burning Jealousy is excellent for punishing Weakness Policy and Swords Dance users such as Metagross, Glastrier and Landorus-T.

  • Body Press is Torkoal's primary offensive option. It his fairly hard, as Torkoal has a naturally high Defense stat.

  • Yawn can cripple Dynamaxed Pokemon, which Torkoal struggles to deal with otherwise.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Eruption is Torkoal's most powerful attack, being able to OHKO the likes of Metagross and Thundurus. It also gives Torkoal a 150 BP Max Flare, a powerful single-target attack and a way to reset sun.

  • Heat Wave is a strong spread move that doesn't rely on Torkoal having high remaining HP, making it more reliable the longer Torkoal is on the field.

  • Earth Power hits Rock- and Fire-types such as Nihilego, Incineroar, and Stakataka. Additionally, it can boost its Torkoal's rather poor Special Defense with Max Quake. Alternatively, Solar Beam hits types Water- and Rock-types such as Tapu Fini and Lapras. Max Overgrowth is useful for not being reliant on sun to dent opposing Water-types, and it can also override opposing terrains by summoning Grassy Terrain.

sets.name: Trick Room Support
sets.description:
• Massive defenses further boosted by Eviolite, immunity to Fake Out, few weaknesses, and a wide supportive movepool make Dusclops a solid Trick Room setter. Moves such as Ally Switch, Will-O-Wisp, and Haze make it great support for teammates like Stakataka, Torkoal, and Glastrier.

  • Night Shade lets Dusclops deal consistent chip damage; it is chosen over other attacks due to Dusclops's poor offensive presence.

  • Dusclops uses Pain Split well due to its low HP stat allowing for increased recovery against most Pokemon.

  • Haze allows Dusclops to stop setup sweepers like Regirock, Rotom-W, and Tapu Fini from snowballing. Additionally, Haze can also remove Intimidate drops for physical teammates like Glastrier and Rhyperior, as well as clearing boosts from Trick Room checks such as Metagross and Celesteela. Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers like Metagross, Rillaboom, and Urshifu-R; alternatively, Ally Switch allows Dusclops to redirect powerful attacks to itself instead of its partner. This is especially useful for absorbing Max Moves, helped further by Dusclops's immunities to Fighting and Normal.

  • Dusclops's EVs allow it to live Life Orb Max Darkness from Galarian Moltres and Life Orb Max Phantasm from Dragapult.

  • Dusclops can run moves like Bulldoze, Brick Break, and Shadow Sneak to activate a teammate's Weakness Policy in place of its last move.

Metagross.overview: Metagross is a solid choice for a bulky attacker due to its insanely high Attack and its resistances to Grass-, Ice- and Fairy-type moves. Furthermore, it is one of the select few Pokemon that has Clear Body, which allows Metagross to stay safe from Intimidate or stat drops from opposing Max Moves. Its large number of resistances and its common weaknesses in Ground, Ghost, Dark, and Fire make it an excellent Weakness Policy user. Metagross appreciates Pokemon that can activate its Weakness Policy such as Spectrier and Tornadus. Despite all of its positive traits, Metagross can be shut down by Pokemon such as Gigantamax Charizard and Spectrier. It is also reliant on Dynamax to make the most of its offensive capabilities.
Metagross.comments:
Other Options

Zen Headbutt allows Metagross to target Pokemon such as Venusaur with a powerful Max Mindstorm whilst setting Psychic Terrain. Bullet Punch is a reliable priority option, but it cuts into Metagross's coverage. Assault Vest is another valid option to allow Metagross to stand up to special attackers like Spectrier and Rotom-H, but such a set is considerably less powerful than Weakness Policy.

sets.name: Weakness Policy
sets.description:
• Iron Head is Metagross's Steel-type attack of choice, as it can flinch foes and is perfectly accurate. Its powerful Max Steelspike is useful for boosting Metagross's already high Defense and can severely damage Glastrier and Grimmsnarl.

  • Stomping Tantrum is used in order to break through Pokemon such as Incineroar and Regieleki with the added bonus of boosting Metagross's Special Defense through Max Quake.

  • Rock Slide is able to hurt Pokemon such as Charizard and Zapdos while Metagross is Dynamaxed. Ice Punch can be run in order to punch holes through Ground- and Grass-types such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Rillaboom.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Regirock's massive physical bulk lets it easily take some of the strongest super effective physical attacks in the format, letting it use Weakness Policy effectively. Additionally, Regirock's Rock typing matches up well against many of the format's Flying-types, like Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, and Charizard.

  • Rock Slide is a reliable STAB move that hits common threats like Zapdos, Thundurus, and Galarian Moltres for super effective damage while also providing a chance to flinch opposing Pokemon. Max Rockfall also sets up sand, improving Regirock's Special Defense.

  • Drain Punch gives Regirock a form of recovery and a way to raise its Attack with Max Knuckle. Body Press is another option that takes advantage of its enormous Defense stat. However, it should be noted that Body Press should only be picked over Drain Punch on Curse sets, where Regirock can take advantage of the Defense boosts.

  • Ice Punch is a great coverage move to hit Ground-types like Landorus-T and Garchomp, as well as Grass-types such as Rillaboom, Venusaur, and Amoonguss.

  • Stomping Tantrum increases Regirock's Special Defense when turned into Max Quake while also giving it coverage against Steel-types such as Heatran and Metagross.

  • Curse is an option that allows Regirock to set up against more passive Pokemon like Grimmsnarl and Incineroar. Both Protect and Curse can be run; however, Regirock will then miss out on crucial coverage.

  • Weakness Policy allows Regirock to take advantage of its bulk to take super effective moves from Pokemon like Kartana and both Urshifu formes and in return fire off a +2 attack.

  • 236 HP EVs minimizes chip damage from moves like G-Max Vinelash while keeping as much HP as possible. 68 Speed EVs allow Regirock to outspeed Landorus-T when Tailwind is up. However, Regirock still is 1 point slower than base 60 Speed Pokemon like Incineroar, Grimmsnarl, and Porygon2. This means that it will underspeed these Pokemon when Trick Room is up, making Regirock very flexible in where it can function.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
• Thanks to Registeel's enormous defenses, it has established itself as a solid bulky Steel-type in the current metagame. It is capable of unleashing some of the most effective Body Presses in the game thanks to its base 150 Defense and access to Iron Defense. In addition to this, Registeel's Clear Body foils many attempts to bring its defenses back into check.

  • Body Press is Registeel's primary source of damage due to its high Defense stat. It's vital in tackling Pokemon that typically check Registeel such as Incineroar, Heatran and Urshifu.

  • Iron Defense and Amnesia are both responsible for making Registeel the defensive monster it is. In late game situations, their defense boosts are pivotal in making Registeel unbeatable by the rest of the opposing team.

  • Protect is the primary option for the last slot that maximizes the recovery gained from Leftovers, allowing for better longevity. Rest is an option that gives Registeel a form of full recovery at the cost of being asleep for two turns. This is generally less of a problem for Registeel, however, due to its bulk.

  • Leftovers is the best item for Registeel, as its tendency to stay on the field allows for maximum recovery, often more than alternatives such as Sitrus Berry.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Due to Garchomp's excellent typing, Attack, and Speed, it has proven to be a threatening setup sweeper in VGC 2021. Its Ground typing gives it a crucial Electric immunity, allowing it to stand up to the mighty Regieleki and potentially set up with Swords Dance in its face.

  • Stomping Tantrum is a reliable Ground-type STAB move for Garchomp which doesn't hit its teammate, unlike Earthquake. However, you can still go with Earthquake instead, which has the benefit of hitting both foes. On the other hand, it is also noteworthy that when Grassy Terrain is active, Earthquake's damage will be halved, while Stomping Tantrum's stays the same. Another noteworthy point is the fact that Earthquake and Stomping Tantrum both have the same Base Power when Garchomp is Dynamaxed.

  • Rock Slide is a crucial coverage move for Garchomp, as it allows it to hit Pokemon such as Zapdos and Galarian Moltres that are immune to its Ground-type move of choice.

  • Swords Dance allows Garchomp to boost its Attack and sweep through teams. Swords Dance is especially good to counter Intimidate, which is often used to suppress Garchomp's attacking presence. Dragon Claw is an option that to hit Dragon-types such as Kingdra and Dragapult while also providing a useful Attack reduction with Max Wyrmwind.

  • Life Orb is useful for increasing Garchomps already massive damage output; however, Lum Berry can be used to prevent burn and sleep from crippling Garchomp. Alternatively, Safety Goggles can be used to completely shut down Venusaur and Amoonguss attempting to sleep Garchomp with Sleep Powder and Spore, respectively.

sets.name: Trick Room Attacker
sets.description:
• Rhyperior uses its low Speed and sky-high Attack to be one of the most dangerous Trick Room attackers in VGC 2021. It also utilizes its excellent bulk combined with Solid Rock to take advantage of Weakness Policy. It is most often seen on Sun teams with a Trick Room setter, as it is able to remove common Venusaur checks such as Thundurus and Rotom-H.

  • Rock Slide is a reliable STAB move to hit common Rock-weak Pokemon such as Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, and Incineroar. When Rhyperior is Dynamaxed, Max Rockfall sets sand, which improves Rhyperior's rather poor Special Defense.

  • High Horsepower is Rhyperior's Ground-type STAB move of choice over Earthquake, as it doesn't hit teammates. It is able to hit Pokemon such as Metagross and Stakataka that resist its Rock Slide.

  • Ice Punch is a crucial coverage move for Rhyperior, as it allows it to hit checks such as Garchomp and Landorus-T that would otherwise threaten it.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Togekiss's bulk and great defensive typing, as well as its variety of support options such as Yawn, Follow Me, and Helping Hand, allow it to be an excellent support Pokemon.

  • Dazzling Gleam lets Togekiss break Focus Sashes and pick off weakened foes even through redirection. Dazzling Gleam also has a 1/8 chance to be a critical hit due to Super Luck, which can deal big damage. Alternatively, Air Slash can hit Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Venusaur harder as well as be a nuisance to slower Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Dusclops with a nasty 60% flinch rate when paired with Serene Grace.

  • Follow Me allows frail teammates such as Urshifu-S and Kartana to fire off attacks without fear of getting blown away by a strong attack, even absorbing any Max Move because they are all single targeting. It also helps with status conditions aimed to cripple teammates, such as burn from Will-O-Wisp and sleep from Spore and Sleep Powder. Follow Me is also excellent at helping setup sweepers such as Rotom-W and Spectrier snowball.

  • Yawn allows Togekiss to pressure Dynamaxed Pokemon to either switch or be put to sleep, either way leaving the opposition severely crippled. Togekiss can also go with Helping Hand, however, which is useful for increasing the damage production of teammates.

  • Babiri Berry allows Togekiss to take attacks from Metagross and Kartana better, while Safety Goggles completely shuts down Sleep Powder and Spore attempts from Venusaur and Amoonguss. Alternatively, Wacan Berry allows it to take hits from Regieleki and Thundurus better.

sets.name: Scope Lens
sets.description:
• Togekiss's excellent offensive coverage, good bulk, and access to Follow Me allows it to be both a potent offensive and supportive presence. Due to its Super Luck and Scope Lens, it can break through many strong Pokemon, with its damage output very hard to slow down.

  • Dazzling Gleam is a very reliable spread move, hitting through redirection cores like Clefairy + Spectrier and Dragapult +Amoonguss. When Dynamaxed,Max Starfall can OHKO Dragapult and Grimmsnarl and acts as Terrain control by setting Misty Terrain.

  • Air Slash is a good secondary STAB that hits what Dazzling Gleam can't, specifically Fire- and Poison-types like Entei and Venusaur. It serves as the base move for Max Airstream, allowing Togekiss to boost its speed in order to outrun threats like of Dragapult, Cinderace, and Zapdos.

  • Heat Wave gives Togekiss the ability to severely damage Pokemon that would otherwise wall it, such as Celesteela, Glastrier, and Kartana. It can also set sun with Max Flare, which is relevant if Togekiss is paired with Fire-types such as Incineroar, Torkoal, and Charizard. Protect can also be used over Heat Wave in order to keep Togekiss around longer and is helpful for stalling out Trick Room turns or a foe's Dynamax.

  • Follow Me is useful for granting safe turns for Togekiss's allies, either by giving them a free turn to set up or helping them avoid a Max Move from an opposing Pokemon in order to attack back with their own powerful blow.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Mamoswine is one of the most threatening Pokemon in the metagame. Between its sky-high Attack stat, great offensive typing, and immunity to Intimidate because of Oblivious, it can blow massive holes in opposing teams.

  • High Horsepower is the chosen Ground-type STAB move and is used over Earthquake as it doesn't hit Mamoswine's teammates. It hits Fire-types such as Incineroar and Entei, as well as Steel-types such as Heatran and Metagross, which would otherwise resist its Ice-type attacks. High Horsepower also turns into Max Quake if you choose to Dynamax Mamoswine, providing useful Special Defense buffs.

  • Icicle Crash is chosen over Icicle Spear because of its consistency. It hit a variety of Pokemon for super effective damage, such as Zapdos, Landorus-T, and Dragapult.

  • Ice Shard is very useful to pick off fast Focus Sash users such as Whimsicott and Regieleki.

  • Mamoswine can run Life Orb to boost its already massive Attack, but it can also run Focus Sash to survive a hit against Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Venusaur.

sets.name: Dynamax Attacker
sets.description:
• Porygon-Z makes use of its amazing Special Attack paired with Adaptability to threaten almost the entire metagame. While its attacking potential is one of the best, its low bulk, average Speed, and need to Dynamax to perform well are often a burden; therefore, it needs to be supported by a redirector such as Clefairy or Togekiss.

  • Hyper Beam lets Porygon-Z unleash a 300 Base Power Max Strike, capable of shredding even bulky foes like Tapu Fini, Incineroar, and Grimmsnarl. Moreover, Max Strike lowers the foe's Speed, allowing Porygon-Z to outspeed Urshifu-R, Garchomp, and Galarian Moltres.

  • Dark Pulse hits Ghost-types such as Spectrier and Dragapult that are immune to Hyper Beam while also lowering their Special Defense when Dynamaxed.

  • Trick Room allows Porygon-Z to function on mixed archetypes that feature slow Pokemon such as Glastrier and Torkoal. Nasty Plot can be used as an alternative to boost Porygon-Z's Special Attack, but it isn't usually needed, as its immediate power is more than enough to threaten the majority of the metagame, and using Nasty Plot would require even more redirection support to function well.

Rotom-Heat.overview: Rotom-H shines more than ever with the amount of Steel- and Grass-types in the current metagame, such as Rillaboom, Kartana, and Celesteela, all of which it can check. Its amazing defensive typing also lets it take on Glastrier, Metagross and Venusaur with relative ease. In addition, it becomes a threatening Pokemon under Dynamax after a Nasty Plot or two. However, it struggles against Pokemon such as Assault Vest Landorus-T, as well as against damage reductions such as Grimmsnarl's Light Screen and Incineroar's Snarl. Further, it relies on Nasty Plot to boost its comparatively meager Special Attack stat, meaning it often has matchups where it is unable to set up and simply dead weight.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
• Overheat allows Rotom-H to hit Steel- and Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Kartana. It is also able to change the weather as Max Flare during Dynamax.

  • Nasty Plot is used to offset Overheat’s Special Attack drop as well as increase Rotom-H's damage output. Rotom-H is typically able to set up easily thanks to its typing.

  • Safety Goggles is used to block sleep moves from Venusaur and Amoonguss, as well as Rage Powder from the latter. Sitrus Berry can be used instead to increase Rotom-H’s longevity.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Rotom-W's typing lets it be a good defensive check to multiple top threats such as Tapu Fini, Lapras, and Charizard. However, it can also be a potent Dynamax sweeper when set up.

  • Hydro Pump is a strong STAB move that can make quick work of Pokemon such as Incineroar, Coalossal, and Rotom-H. It also grants access to a powerful Max Geyser, which can be used to set rain.

  • Thunderbolt hits Tapu Fini, Galarian Moltres, and Celesteela for big damage. Additionally, it can be used to set Electric Terrain, though it is worth mentioning that Rotom-W cannot take advantage of it due to Levitate.

  • Rotom-W can easily set up Nasty Plots due to it being able to stonewall many top threats such as Landorus-T, Garchomp and Spectrier. This can allow it to easily set up sweeps, especially with redirection or Fake Out support from Amoonguss or Incineroar, respectively.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Heatran packs a high Special Attack and access to both Max Steelspike and Max Quake to boost both of its defenses, making it a potent special attacker that's equally difficult to take down.

  • Heat Wave gives Heatran a consistent spread move while also serving as the base move for its powerful Max Flare. Its ability to set sun for itself is incredibly useful, strengthening its Fire-type attacks and covering for its Water weakness.

  • Flash Cannon is useful for hitting the numerous Ice- and Fairy-types in the metagame like Glastrier, Clefairy, and Grimmsnarl. Heatran also appreciates the Defense boost from Max Steelspike, which allows it to take a Max Quake from Garchomp at +1 Defense.

  • Earth Power complements Heatran's STAB move combination well by nailing Fire-types like Incineroar while also being helpful for hitting Regieleki and Nihilego.

  • The Speed EVs allow Heatran to outrun Adamant Tyranitar as well as Pheromosa in Tailwind. The HP investment combined with a Shuca Berry allows it to easily survive a Max Quake from Landorus-T.

Regigigas.overview: With its enormous base 160 Attack stat, great defensive stats, and a single weakness, Regigigas rivals even Restricted Pokemon in terms of raw strength and bulk. Regigigas is even capable of firing off continuous 150 Base Power Max Strikes. It also has a fair amount of decent coverage moves including the elemental punches, High Horsepower, and Darkest Lariat. However, it has an obvious downside in Slow Start, making it extremely reliant on Weezing as a partner to remove this burden.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Giga Impact provides a 150 Base Power Max Strike as Regigigas's primary damage dealing option that also drops the opposing Pokemon's Speed as an added bonus.

  • High Horsepower is Regigigas's method of breaking through opposing Steel-types such as Metagross, Stakataka and Heatran that Giga Impact would otherwise struggle to hit. It also boosts its ally's Special Defense with Max Quake, which can be vital for extra survivability against Spectrier and Rotom-H.

  • Ice Punch offers Regigigas a way of breaking through Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Garchomp much more easily. Thunder Punch, on the other hand, helps deal with many Pokemon weak to Electric such as Galarian Moltres and Tapu Fini, and it can also set Electric Terrain with Max Lightning to block sleep moves from Venusaur and Amoonguss.

  • Protect lets Regigigas stall out a few turns of Slow Start when Weezing is not on the field.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Ice Beam lets Cresselia hit Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Zapdos fairly hard while not having to invest in Special Attack. Icy Wind is useful for speed control, supporting middling-Speed Pokemon such as Heatran and Tapu Fini while also canceling out opposing Max Airstream.

  • Cresselia makes excellent use of Trick Room thanks to its solid defenses and access to Levitate, both of which often make it hard to remove easily.

  • Helping Hand is very useful for increasing Cresselia's partner's offensive pressure, as it typically has very little of its own. It pairs especially well with Pokemon like Glastrier that often get inflicted by Intimidate from Incineroar, making up for the Attack drop.

  • Ally Switch allows Cresselia to sponge hits such as Max Moves that its partner would rather avoid. Moonblast OHKOes any Urshifu-S not carrying a Focus Sash. Psychic hits Urshifu-R, Venusaur, and Amoonguss, but it is very weak on neutral targets.

  • Mental Herb ensures Cresselia can effectively set Trick Room without being disrupted by Taunt or Encore. Colbur Berry allows Cresselia to survive a Choice Band-boosted Wicked Blow from Urshifu-S, while Sitrus Berry gives it some nice recovery.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• With a solid base 135 Attack stat, ability in Sand Rush, and great typing, Excadrill can easily find its way onto any sand team. Excadrill's typing allows it to be a proficient Dynamax attacker, with its Max Quake and Max Steelspike boosting its defenses. This makes Tyranitar a brilliant partner, as, while in sand, Excadrill can outspeed any threat in the metagame.

  • Earthquake is Excadrill's primary choice for a Ground STAB move, as it turns into a strong Max Quake while also being a decent spread option outside of Dynamax. High Horsepower is another option that has a higher single target Base Power at the cost of a small amount of accuracy; however, its main strength is that Grassy Terrain from Rillaboom doesn't decrease its power unlike Earthquake.

  • Iron Head is Excadrill's strongest physical Steel-type move, allowing for defense boosts as Max Steelspike as well as offering the chance to flinch when not Dynamaxed.

  • Rock Slide is a good coverage move for Excadrill that can help it overcome the likes of Charizard, Zapdos and, Galarian Moltres; it becomes the base for Max Rockfall, allowing Excadrill to set the sand in the absence of Tyranitar. It also enables the chance to flinch both opposing Pokemon due to Excadrill's blistering Speed when in sand.

  • Swords Dance gives Excadrill the opportunity to become a potent setup sweeper, as well as the potential to undo any Intimidate drops from the likes of Incineroar or Landorus-T.

  • Life Orb is the main item for Excadrill, as it allows for a consistent boost to its damage output at the cost of some recoil. Weakness Policy is a great alternative due to Excadrill's desire to Dynamax, giving it the necessary bulk in conjunction with the chance to boost its defenses. Focus Sash is a solid item for Excadrill due to its poor bulk outside of Dynamax, and it is best used alongside Swords Dance to give it a good opportunity for a turn of setup.

  • An Adamant nature is best used when using Sand Rush, as partners such as Tyranitar can easily set sand for Excadrill making up for the lack of Speed-boosting nature. A Jolly nature with Mold Breaker can be considered to act as a check to Rotom-H and Rotom-W.

Whimsicott.overview: In a metagame packed with multiple lightning-fast attackers, having reliable speed control can be the difference between a win and a loss, which is exactly what Whimsicott can consistently provide. It has seemingly unlimited options for support moves that can either enable its partner or disrupt the opposing Pokemon. Its Fairy-type STAB moves also certify it as an offensive threat capable of aiding its partner in powerful double targets or outright OHKOing Urshifu-S. However, as Whimsicott is so geared toward a supporting role, it's often reliant on its partner for to make progress in the game. A well-timed Trick Room from the opponent will pretty much ruin anything that Whimsicott hopes to set up as well.
Whimsicott.comments:
Other Options

Energy Ball is an option for an extra attacking move, though Whimsicott loses some if its supportive capability. Trick Room can be used for its surprise factor to counteract opposing speed control, but there are typically few chances to use it well. Charm is a solid option for crippling opposing physical attackers; however, Whimsicott would much rather spend its turn enabling its partner instead of annoying the opponent.

sets.name: Tailwind Support
sets.description:
• Moonblast is Whimsicott's preffered attacking option for doing significantly more damage to Garchomp and Galarian Moltres, but Dazzling Gleam has a niche in pairing well with strong Max Moves to pick up a KO and score some extra damage on the remaining foe.

  • Whimsicott's Tailwind is practically guaranteed thanks to Prankster, allowing it and its partner to outspeed the metagame's fastest threats such as Regieleki, Dragapult, and Venusaur in sun.

  • Helping Hand has a wider range of usefulness, being able to aid physical attackers and function within Psychic Terrain. Fake Tears, however, is recommend if Whimsicott is paired with strong special attackers like Spectrier and Zapdos.

  • Protect keeps Whimsicott safe from Fake Outs aimed at it to prevent Tailwind from being set up. Alternatively, Taunt is notable for shutting down opposing support Pokemon including Amoonguss, Tornadus, and Porygon2.

  • The combination of Switcheroo and Eject Button is useful for disrupting a foe's Dynamax, as they will be forced to switch out if the Eject Button is activated by a partner.

  • Focus Sash is the recommended item, but as Whimsicott often finds its niche on hyper offensive teams, there's a very high chance that Focus Sash may already have been taken. In this case, Coba Berry makes for a solid replacement, allowing it to stomach a stray Max Airstream or Hurricane.

sets.name: Trapper
sets.description:
• Gothitelle makes use of Shadow Tag and its wide range of supportive moves such as Helping Hand and Fake Out to aid partners like Politoed, Kingdra, and Thundurus.

  • Gothitelle can set up Trick Room fairly easily if it traps passive foes like Gigantamax Lapras, Porygon2, and Amoonguss. Offensive partners like Glastrier and Kingdra appreciate Shadow Tag easing prediction.

  • Protect is important on Gothitelle, as it allows for it to keep the Shadow Tag trap. Generally, it will want to use Protect very often in order to keep itself safe for as long as possible. Psychic allows Gothitelle to generate some offensive pressure of its own.

  • Focus Sash lets Gothitelle guarantee Trick Room in the face of powerful attacks like Max Phantasm from Dragapult and Max Darkness from Galarian Moltres. Mental Herb allows it to avoid being completely crippled by stray Taunt or Encore, while Lum Berry keeps it safe from status like Torkoal's Yawn and Amoonguss's Spore.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Amoonguss functions as a potent support Pokemon in the metagame, boasting amazing bulk and having access to a wide array of support options in redirection, recovery in Regenerator, and status infliction. Furthermore, its low Speed helps it function as a potential check to Trick Room attackers such as Porygon2 and Regirock.

  • Amoonguss's primary means of offense comes in the form of Sludge Bomb, which can be used to thwart popular Fairy-type Pokemon such as Clefairy and Tapu Fini. Meanwhile, Pollen Puff is a good support move to help heal Amoonguss's partner Pokemon. Clear Smog can be used if the team struggles against setup sweepers like Tapu Fini, Spectrier, and Galarian Moltres.

  • Spore is used to put opposing non-Grass-type Pokemon to sleep such as Torkoal, Clefairy, and Garchomp. Putting opposing Pokemon to sleep gives Amoonguss's teammates such as Landorus-T and Galarian Moltres free turns to set up and shut down a Dynamaxed Pokemon and helps stall out Trick Room.

  • Rage Powder allows Amoonguss to redirect incoming attacks onto itself while allowing its partner Pokemon to set up or dish out damage. This is especially useful in the Dynamax format to soak up Max Moves.

  • Coba Berry lets Amoonguss stay safe while facing Max Airstream users like Thundurus, Landorus-T, and Galarian Moltres. Focus Sash, on the other hand, can be used to survive any one move that could potentially OHKO Amoonguss.

  • 220 HP EVs, 188 Defense EVs, and a Relaxed nature let Amoonguss take Glastrier's Icicle Crash, while 0 Speed IVs allow it to underspeed Regirock, Porygon2, and some Glastrier variants.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
• With Ferrothorn's great defensive typing and solid natural bulk, it is able to be a consistent and very respectable win condition against many top threats, such as Porygon2 and Landorus-T.

  • Body Press is Ferrothorn's sole offensive option. After Ferrothorn has used Iron Defense a few times, it's capable of putting dents in a majority of the metagame, including Rillaboom, Incineroar, and Kartana.

  • Ferrothorn can easily set up Iron Defense in the face of many attackers. After an Iron Defense, it is basically untouchable by a majority of the physical Pokemon in the metagame, including Landorus-T and Glastrier.

  • Leech Seed is a way for Ferrothorn to recover while slowly chipping at its foes. It is excellent for wearing down Pokemon without reliable recovery, like Dragapult and Thundurus.

  • 212 HP EVs maximize Leftovers recovery, while 252 Special Defense EVs allow Ferrothorn to better stand up to strong special attackers like Regieleki and Spectrier.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
• Volcarona's access to Rage Powder, Steel resistance, and Flame Body ability make it a good choice as a supportive Pokemon, as it is able to handle the likes of Zacian-C and Necrozma-DM with ease. It also comes with a hefty base 135 Special Attack stat that allows it to go on the offensive when needed.

  • Overheat allows Volcarona to always ensure KOs on Jolly Zacian-C and Metagross. Heat Wave is a consistent spread option that doesn't drop Volcarona's Special Attack stat at the cost of lower Base Power.

  • Struggle Bug allows Volcarona to reduce the impact of specially attacking threats such as Kyogre and Calyrex-S, whereas Will-O-Wisp cripples physical attackers such as Thundurus and Groudon.

  • Focus Sash is the item of choice for Volcarona, allowing it to absorb at least two attacks if it uses Rage Powder immediately.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Terrakion's great offensive typing, fairly high Attack stat, and base 108 Speed allows it to outpace and dominate some of the biggest threats in the metagame such as Zapdos, Galarian Moltres, Charizard and Urshifu-S. Beat Up users such as Dragapult and Whimsicott can also use Terrakion's Justified to boost its Attack to extremely high levels.

  • Rock Slide is Terrakion's Rock-type STAB of choice, as it is a fairly consistent spread move with a chance to flinch that threatens opponents such as Galarian Moltres, Zapdos, and Torkoal. Max Rockfall can be used to break momentum of weather-based teams by setting up sand.

  • Close Combat deals massive damage to opponents such as Urshifu-S, Glastrier, and Incineroar, but the drop in defenses can put Terrakion in a difficult situation. Using Close Combat is a good way to secure a hit, because Rock Slide can miss and ruin a game. Terrakion can also increase its Attack stat by using Max Knuckle in order to become even more threatening.

  • Helping Hand is a great support move, as it gives a boost to Terrakion's teammates when attacking. In general, it helps offensive teammates such as Dragapult, Venusaur, and Torkoal deal with bulkier threats when Terrakion hasn't used Dynamax. Stomping Tantrum is a coverage option that hits metagame staples like Metagross. It can also be used to boost Special Defense when Dynamaxed.

  • White Herb lets Terrakion stay on the field against Intimidate users, such as Incineroar and Landorus-T, it's useful to ignore drops in Terrakion's defenses from Close Combat. It also prevents Terrakion's stats from being lowered by Max Moves such as Max Wyrmwind and Max Phantasm once. Lum Berry allows Terrakion to shake off a multitude of status inducing attacks such as Dragapult's Will-O-Wisp, Amoonguss's Spore and Venusaur's Sleep Powder.

Tornadus.overview: In a metagame where Tailwind is more important than ever, Tornadus has solidified itself as a staple support Pokemon, mostly alongside Kyogre. Its access to Rain Dance and Taunt allows it to easily enable its partners while carrying a strong Hurricane for when Tornadus needs to go on the offensive. However, its Flying typing makes it much more vulnerable to getting shut down by Prankster Taunt or Fake Out due to its inability to make use of Terrains. Its support movepool is very limited, which can make it seem underwhelming as a utility Pokemon compared to Grimmsnarl or Amoonguss. Tornadus also faces heavy competition with Whimsicott as a Tailwind setter, since it's faster and has a bigger support movepool, so Tornadus is often limited to being used on teams utilizing Kyogre.
Tornadus.comments:
Other Options

Icy Wind grants even more speed control on top of Tailwind, notably combating opposing attempts at Speed boosting from Max Airstream and Tailwind. Heat Wave gives Tornadus a spread move option and a strong way to hit Kartana. Brutal Swing helps activate Weakness Policy for partners such as Metagross and Solgaleo. Safety Goggles can be useful for denying sleep but is only useful if there's an Amoonguss or Venusaur on the opponent's team.

sets.name: Tailwind Support
sets.description:
• Hurricane's higher Base Power is preferred because of how often it finds itself with Kyogre. If it isn't with Kyogre however, Air Slash can be used to avoid Hurricane's shaky accuracy.

  • Tailwind is very easy to set up thanks to Prankster, and it grants Tornadus and its partner the ability to outspeed even the likes of Regieleki and Calyrex-S.

  • Taunt provides a means of shutting down supportive Pokemon like Amoonguss and Porygon2, while Rain Dance puts Kyogre at ease against other weather setters like Groudon and Torkoal.

  • Focus Sash lets Tornadus take a heavy hit after getting Tailwind up, although Wacan Berry is a good alternative to survive an attack from the likes of Regieleki and Zapdos if a teammate is already using Focus Sash. Alternatively Mental Herb gives Tornadus a guaranteed way to set Tailwind in front of Whimsicott.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
• Defiant Thundurus is an excellent Pokemon to use in the face of common Intimidate users like Incineroar and Landorus-T. Its high Speed and Attack coupled with decent defenses make it hard to counter easily.

  • Fly is used to give Thundurus access to Max Airstream, acting as both a powerful STAB move and a reliable means of speed control.

  • Superpower lets Thundurus pummel Incineroar and Tyranitar, gives it a strong move to click in the face of Lightning Rod and allows it to boost its Attack with Max Knuckle.

  • Lash Out is a solid filler option on Assault Vest sets, as it lets Thundurus use Max Darkness to lower foes' Special Defense, something special attacking teammates like Venusaur and Spectrier can capitalize on.

  • Life Orb will allow Thundurus to notably OHKO Incineroar with Max Airstream at +1. Assault Vest is helpful for letting Thundurus better check prominent special attackers such as Spectrier and Tapu Lele.

Landorus-Therian.overview: Access to Intimidate and a strong Ground / Flying typing as well as a high base 145 Attack stat have made Landorus-T one of the strongest Pokemon in the format. A metagame dominated by Fire- and Steel-types, such as Heatran and Metagross, allows it to shine even further due to the offensive pressure it puts on them. Because of this, Landorus-T also makes for an excellent Dynamax user, dishing out powerful Max Moves such as Max Airstream and Max Quake. Intimidate is a vital tool in as it allows the team to mitigate damage from strong physical threats such as Rillaboom and Kartana. However, Landorus-T packs a few significant downsides, including a 4x weakness to Ice, so it falls very quickly to Porygon2 and Glastrier. It is also very common for teams to include Pokemon with abilities such as Defiant and Competitive, such as Thundurus and Milotic, in order to punish Landorus-T for switching in.
Landorus-Therian.comments:
Other Options

Landorus-T makes for a decent Choice Scarf user, as it will outspeed both Dragapult and Cinderace and deal significant damage to them, though it is lacking in power. Landorus-T can utilize Choice Band for a stronger Earthquake but becomes useless in Dynamax.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Earthquake allows Landorus-T to hit all of the popular Steel-type restricted Pokemon like Incineroar and Metagross for super effective damage. Max Quake is also an extremely powerful Max Move, allowing Landorus-T to boost its Special Defense while dishing out massive single target damage.

  • Rock Slide is a great spread move that gives Landorus-T a better matchup against Flying-types such as Galarian Moltres and Zapdos while also allowing it to use Max Rockfall to change the weather in the face of sun or rain teams. Fly, on the other hand, is mostly used for a powerful Max Airstream, which lets Landorus-T boost its Speed while doing big damage to Grass-types like Amoonguss and Rillaboom.

  • Swords Dance allows Landorus-T to stand up better against Dynamaxed threats such as Metagross. +2 Max Quake can even OHKO it before it gets any defensive boosts from its own Max Moves.

  • Lum Berry is the preferred item due to the prevalence of Will-O-Wisp and Amoonguss's Spore in the metagame. This allows Landorus-T to switch into any status move and shrug it off for free. Life Orb allows Landorus-T to dish out increased damage but leaves it as a prime target for Will-O-Wisp and sleep moves.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Earthquake allows Landorus-T to deal big damage to many of the most common Pokemon in the metagame such as Incineroar and OHKO Regieleki.

  • Fly is mainly used when Landorus-T is Dynamaxed, as it allows it to fire off super strong STAB Max Airstreams. At +1 Speed, it can outspeed Thundurus, Kartana, Urshifu-S, and Urshifu-R. Fly can also be useful in some late-game situations outside of Dynamax when it can be used to force opposing Max Moves to miss while it is in the air. Superpower is sometimes an option when the team lacks a consistent means of hitting Kartana and Ferrothorn for super effective damage. Max Knuckle can also be nice for boosting Landorus-T's Attack stat.

  • U-turn maximizes Landorus-T's pivoting potential by allowing it to Intimidate opposing Pokemon and then switch out into one of its teammates.

  • This set leans into Landorus-T's defensive capabilities and allows it to act more as a pivot while still serving as a strong offensive option while Dynamaxed. The EV spread allows it to survive a variety of super effective moves while Dynamaxed, including -1 Attack Icicle Crash from Glastrier, Max Geyser from Rotom-W, and Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R.

Incineroar.overview: Incineroar's bulk and dynamic movepool make it arguably the best supporting Pokemon in the format, primarily offering move options like Fake Out, Snarl, and Taunt and utilizing Intimidate and Parting Shot to weather the opponent's offensive. Its typing is perfect for checking the multitudes of Ghost- and Steel-type Pokemon dominating the metagame, like Spectrier and Kartana. The unique supportive options provided by Incineroar make it an easy inclusion for most teams. However, STAB moves from Rotom-W and Choice Band Urshifu-S and Urshifu-R will surely cause the cat to cower, and the prevalence of Fighting- and Ground-type coverage on common Pokemon, like Glastrier's Close Combat and Rillaboom's High Horsepower, enables them to continue hitting Incineroar fairly hard, even after an Attack drop from Intimidate. Incineroar's base 60 Speed also means it is outsped by the vast majority of the metagame.
Incineroar.comments:
Other Options

Assault Vest can be used to better take strong special attacks from Regieleki or Tapu Fini. An Impish nature allows Incineroar to safely take Max Quake and Close Combat from Adamant Landorus-T and Urshifu-S, respectively. Will-O-Wisp and Burning Jealousy are options that punish common setup attackers such as Swords Dance Garchomp and Landorus-T. Will-O-Wisp has lower accuracy but will always burn when it hits. On the other hand, Burning Jealousy is a nice spread option for Incineroar, but it requires the foe to boost a stat in order to burn. Close Combat hits Dark-types like opposing Incineroar and Rock-types like Nihilego and Stakataka much harder than Flare Blitz. Incineroar's respectable base 115 Attack makes it a potential Dynamax candidate and, if running Close Combat, offers coveted Max Knuckle boosts. Weakness Policy is a fringe option that further amplifies the threat of Incineroar when Dynamaxed. 84 Speed EVs can be used to reach 91 Speed, outspeeding a fully invested Amoonguss.

sets.name: Support
sets.description:
• Flare Blitz is a necessity on Incineroar, providing relevant damage output against Grass- and Steel-types like Venusaur, Rillaboom, and Metagross. Incineroar's sizeable bulk mitigates the impact of the recoil.

  • Parting Shot minimizes the damage the opponent's threats can dish out while resetting Intimidate and Fake Out. It combines well with Incineroar's low Speed as well, safely bringing a teammate in when the danger has passed.

  • Taunt provides utility against opposing support Pokemon like Grimmsnarl and Porygon2. Darkest Lariat is a secondary damage option, useful for hitting Pokemon that shrug off Flare Blitz like Charizard and Rotom-W while also ignoring Defense boosts from Max Steelspike.

  • Sitrus Berry is slightly preferred over Figy Berry because it activates more consistently. Safety Goggles allows Incineroar to better check Venusaur and Amoonguss. Shuca Berry gives Incineroar survivability against powerful Max Quakes from Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Mamoswine.

  • The defensive investment allows Incineroar to take strong physical attacks like Urshifu-S's Close Combat after an Intimidate and powerful special attacks such as +2 Max Airstream from Galarian Moltres.

sets.name: Trick Room
sets.description:
• With its Ghost typing and Disguise, Mimikyu is a unique supportive presence in the current metagame. Disguise allows Mimikyu to absorb a hit from the vast majority of the metagame, and then set Trick Room largely undeterred. It also comes with a good amount of other supportive options in Will-O-Wisp and Taunt.

  • Shadow Sneak is Mimikyu's primary attacking move due to its middling Speed tier being less than ideal in Trick Room. Shadow Sneak can support partners such as Weakness Policy Metagross.

  • Taunt is an option to lower the impact of opposing supportive Pokemon such as Porygon2 and Amoonguss. Play Rough serves as a method to overcome offensive Dark-types such as Galarian Moltres and Urshifu-S. Phantom Force is a higher Base Power Ghost-type option that can waste opposing Dynamax turns.

  • Will-O-Wisp lets Mimikyu significantly reduce the damage output of the biggest physically attacking threats in the metagame such as Metagross, Thundurus, and Landorus-T.

  • Mental Herb stops Taunt from blocking Trick Room a majority of the time.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description:
• Specially offensive Tapu Koko is a good choice for hitting the metagame's bulky Water-types like Kyogre, Lapras, and Tapu Fini. Its Speed tier gives it a notable leg up on other Electric-types like Rotom-W and Zapdos, as it can outrun the likes of Kartana and Thundurus.

  • Thunderbolt is typically preferred as the Electric-type STAB move of choice, but Thunder can be used for a stronger Max Lightning and also has synergy with Kyogre thanks to Drizzle.

  • Dazzling Gleam gives Tapu Koko a reliable spread move as well as a powerful Max Starfall, which is great for hitting Grimmsnarl and Dragapult.

  • Volt Switch lets Tapu Koko quickly pivot into a partner while still doing respectable damage. This is particularly helpful for baiting Max Quake and then switching to a Ground-immune ally. Alternatively, Electroweb is useful for providing reliable speed control.

sets.name: Physical Attacker
sets.description:
• Physical Tapu Koko is notable for hitting many common Water- and Grass-type Pokemon like Kyogre and Rillaboom harder than special variants.

  • Brave Bird is Tapu Koko's main coverage move, allowing it to hit Ground-types such as Groudon and Landorus-T while also boosting its Speed with Max Airstream.

  • U-turn is used to let Tapu Koko act as a fast pivot.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
• Choice Specs Tapu Lele is a powerful attacker that additionally assists its teammates by blocking priority moves with Psychic Surge. As it sets up Psychic Terrain automatically and deals more damage with regular moves thanks to Choice Specs, it is typically only worth Dynamaxing Tapu Lele to tank a strong attack.

  • Psychic is Tapu Lele's most powerful STAB move, capable of 2HKOing all but the bulkiest non-resistant Pokemon and even denting Dynamaxed Pokemon such as offensive Landorus-T and Thundurus.

  • Moonblast lets Tapu Lele hit Incineroar decently hard and deals massive damage to other Dark-types like Urshifu-S, Galarian Moltres, and Grimmsnarl.

  • Dazzling Gleam lets Tapu Lele damage both foes at once, which also notably allows it to bypass redirection.

  • Shadow Ball deals heavy damage to Metagross and provides super effective coverage for opposing Psychic-types, such as Cresselia and opposing Tapu Lele, while Thunderbolt lets Tapu Lele hit Celesteela as hard as possible.

  • A Timid nature with 252 Speed EVs allows Tapu Lele to outspeed the likes of Landorus-T, Galarian Moltres, and Rotom-H.

Tapu Fini.overview: Thanks to a wide array of set options, a generally good movepool and access to Misty Surge, Tapu Fini establishes itself as a true jack of all trades. Tapu Fini is typically used as a more supportive Pokemon, supporting the team with Misty Terrain which is helpful against common status spreaders such as Amoonguss, Venusaur, and Spectrier. Offensive Tapu Fini, thanks to its positive matchups against Galarian Moltres and Incineroar, is a very potent pick. Unfortunately, It also has weaknesses to some of the most common offensive presences in the metagame, most notably Regieleki, Zapdos and Kartana. What distinguishes Tapu Fini from the rest is the great ability and excellent utility as a bulky water.
Tapu Fini.comments:
Other Options

Tapu Fini may also choose to use a Choice item such as Choice Scarf or Choice Specs.
